Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I pulled up to the curb just as two travelers waved me down, their arms full of heavy suitcases. They looked exhausted, grateful, and asked if I could help load their bags and if they could split the fare. As a taxi driver, I knew what was expected: be helpful, courteous, and get them to their destination efficiently. I started to get out of the car, but my phone buzzed. It was a message from the synagogue—someone in the community had passed away, and they needed exactly one more person to make the minyan for the funeral prayer. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen. My heart pounded. I looked at the travelers, their hopeful faces, and then at the message, feeling the weight of my responsibility as a Jew. I was torn between my duty to my passengers and my obligation to my faith and community. The seconds stretched, and I stood frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice between delivering professional service and honoring a sacred tradition.
